title: Exodus Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Exodus chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Exodus Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Exodus Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Exodus 6:2, what name did God say He is to Moses?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:2 states that God said unto Moses, 'I am the LORD.'

questions.question: Who did God say He appeared to by the name God Almighty, according to Exodus 6:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:3 says God appeared unto Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob by the name God Almighty.

questions.question: What land did God establish His covenant to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, according to Exodus 6:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Canaan
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:4 mentions God established a covenant to give them the land of Canaan.

questions.question: What did God say He heard and remembered in Exodus 6:5?
options: The groaning of the children of Israel in bondage
questions.correctAnswer: The groaning of the children of Israel in bondage
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:5 states God heard the groaning of the children of Israel whom the Egyptians kept in bondage and remembered His covenant.

questions.question: According to Exodus 6:6, how will God redeem the children of Israel?
options: With a stretched out arm and great judgments
questions.correctAnswer: With a stretched out arm and great judgments
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:6 says God will redeem Israel with a stretched out arm and with great judgments.

questions.question: What relationship does God promise to have with the children of Israel in Exodus 6:7?
options: A God to them and they shall be His people
questions.correctAnswer: A God to them and they shall be His people
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:7 states God will take Israel as His people and be their God.

questions.question: Who did Moses speak to in Exodus 6:9, even though they did not listen?
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:9 says Moses spoke to the children of Israel but they did not hearken to him.

questions.question: What did the LORD instruct Moses to tell Pharaoh in Exodus 6:11?
options: Let the children of Israel go out of his land
questions.correctAnswer: Let the children of Israel go out of his land
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:11 commands Moses to tell Pharaoh to let Israel go out of Egypt.

questions.question: How did Moses describe himself to the LORD in Exodus 6:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Of uncircumcised lips
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:12 shows Moses telling the LORD he is of uncircumcised lips.

questions.question: Who are the sons of Levi mentioned in Exodus 6:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:16 lists the sons of Levi as Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 6:1 says that Pharaoh will let the Israelites go with a strong hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:1 states Pharaoh shall let them go and drive them out with a strong hand.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 6:20 says that Amram married a woman named Elisheba.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:20 indicates Amram took Jochebed his father's sister as wife, not Elisheba.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 6:23, Aaron's wife bore him four sons.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:23 records Aaron's wife Elisheba bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Exodus 6:6: 'I will bring you out from under the burdens of the _______, and I will rid you out of their bondage.'
questions.correctAnswer: Egyptians
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:6 says God will bring Israel out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Exodus 6:3: 'And I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, by the name of God Almighty, but by my name ______ was I not known to them.'
questions.correctAnswer: JEHOVAH
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:3 states God was not known to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob by the name JEHOVAH.

medium.title: Exodus Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Exodus Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Exodus 6, what biblical truth would you share about God's power and deliverance?
options: God will deliver His people with a strong hand and great judgments
God allows trials without any plan for deliverance
Deliverance depends solely on human strength and wisdom
God will deliver only after many generations
questions.correctAnswer: God will deliver His people with a strong hand and great judgments
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:1 and 6:6 teach that God will use a strong hand and great judgments to bring deliverance, showing His power and faithfulness. This encourages trust and perseverance in trials.

questions.question: How does Exodus 6 emphasize the importance of trusting God's covenant promises in difficult times?
options: God remembers His covenant and will bring His people into the promised land
God forgets His promises when His people suffer
The covenant is conditional on human success
Promises are symbolic and not to be taken literally
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers His covenant and will bring His people into the promised land
questions.explanation: Verses 6:4-5 show God’s remembrance of His covenant and His promise to give the land of Canaan, encouraging believers to trust God's faithfulness even under hardship.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because others do not listen to their witness. Based on Exodus 6, what encouragement can you offer about obedience and God's timing?
options: Do not be discouraged; God has charged you, even if the people do not heed immediately
If people do not listen, stop sharing the message
Only speak when everyone listens attentively
The message should be changed to please others
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be discouraged; God has charged you, even if the people do not heed immediately
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:9 and 6:11-13 show Moses obeying God’s command despite Israel’s initial resistance, teaching perseverance and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: What does Exodus 6 teach about humility and self-awareness in serving God, especially when facing challenges?
options: Moses acknowledges his limitations but still obeys God
Moses claims to be perfect and without fault
Self-confidence without humility is the key to success
Avoid confronting challenges by hiding weaknesses
questions.correctAnswer: Moses acknowledges his limitations but still obeys God
questions.explanation: In verses 6:12 and 6:30, Moses expresses concern about his 'uncircumcised lips' yet continues to obey, teaching humility and faithfulness despite personal insecurities.

questions.question: How does the genealogy in Exodus 6:14-25 teach us about honoring family and heritage in spiritual leadership?
options: God establishes leadership through family lines, showing respect for heritage
Spiritual leadership is unrelated to family or lineage
Genealogy is irrelevant to God's plan
Only individuals matter, not their family background
questions.correctAnswer: God establishes leadership through family lines, showing respect for heritage
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:14-25 lists the families of Levi and the lineage of Moses and Aaron, highlighting God's plan through established family lines and the importance of honoring heritage in service.

questions.question: A believer struggles with patience in witnessing to others. What does Exodus 6 teach about perseverance in sharing God's word?
options: Keep speaking God's word even if people do not immediately listen
Stop sharing if initial responses are negative
Change the message to make it more acceptable
Share only with those who agree
questions.correctAnswer: Keep speaking God's word even if people do not immediately listen
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:9 records that Israel did not heed Moses because of their anguish, yet Moses continued to speak as God commanded (6:11-13), teaching perseverance in evangelism.

questions.question: How does Exodus 6 encourage believers to rely on God rather than their own abilities when facing opposition?
options: God reassures Moses despite his feelings of inadequacy
Rely only on personal strength to overcome challenges
Ignore God's guidance and act independently
Avoid difficult tasks to prevent failure
questions.correctAnswer: God reassures Moses despite his feelings of inadequacy
questions.explanation: In Exodus 6:29-30, God commands Moses to speak to Pharaoh despite Moses’ concern about his 'uncircumcised lips,' showing reliance on God over self.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 6 teaches that God’s deliverance is guaranteed because He remembers His covenant and acts on behalf of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:5-8 clearly states God hears Israel’s groaning, remembers His covenant, and will bring them out and give them the promised land, assuring deliverance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 6, Moses was confident in his ability to convince Pharaoh without God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:12 and 6:30 show Moses expressing doubt about his ability to be heard because of his 'uncircumcised lips,' indicating his reliance on God’s help, not confidence in himself.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: God said to Moses, "I am the LORD, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I will rid you out of their bondage, and I will redeem you with a stretched out arm, and with great _____."
questions.correctAnswer: judgments
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:6 states God will redeem Israel with a stretched out arm and with great judgments, emphasizing His powerful deliverance over bondage.

questions.question: What lesson about God’s identity and revelation can be drawn from Exodus 6:2-3 regarding faith and trust?
options: God reveals Himself as LORD and by the name JEHOVAH, deepening the relationship with His people
God is unknown and distant from His people
Names of God are unimportant for faith
Faith does not depend on knowing God’s name
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals Himself as LORD and by the name JEHOVAH, deepening the relationship with His people
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:2-3 shows God identifying Himself as LORD and JEHOVAH, indicating His personal and covenantal relationship with His people, encouraging trust.

questions.question: How does Exodus 6 teach about God’s role in family and community life through the genealogy of Levi’s descendants?
options: God ordains family lines for priestly service, showing divine order in community leadership
Family background is irrelevant to God’s plan
Community leadership is random and unstructured
Genealogy is only for historical interest
questions.correctAnswer: God ordains family lines for priestly service, showing divine order in community leadership
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:16-25 details Levi’s descendants, including Moses and Aaron, indicating God’s intentional design for leadership and service within families and the community.

questions.question: A believer feels unqualified to serve God publicly. What truth from Exodus 6 can help them overcome this hesitation?
options: God chooses and empowers imperfect people like Moses and Aaron
Only perfect people can serve God
Qualifications are based on human merit only
Avoid serving if you feel inadequate
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses and empowers imperfect people like Moses and Aaron
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:12, 6:30 show Moses’ feelings of inadequacy, yet God uses him and Aaron to lead, teaching that God empowers those He calls despite their weaknesses.

questions.question: How does Exodus 6 encourage believers to practice faith and obedience even when they do not see immediate results?
options: Moses obeys God’s command despite Israel’s initial resistance
Stop obeying if results are delayed
Ignore God’s commands if circumstances are hard
questions.correctAnswer: Moses obeys God’s command despite Israel’s initial resistance
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:9 and 6:11-13 show Moses continuing to obey God’s instructions even when Israel does not listen, teaching steadfast faith and obedience.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity in leadership can be learned from Exodus 6 regarding Moses and Aaron’s role?
options: Leaders must faithfully carry out God’s commands despite difficulties
Ignore God’s instructions to please people
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must faithfully carry out God’s commands despite difficulties
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:26-27 show Moses and Aaron being charged by God to lead Israel out, emphasizing faithful obedience and integrity in leadership.

hard.title: Exodus Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Exodus Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Exodus 6:3, God reveals a name by which He was not known to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. What is this name?
questions.correctAnswer: JEHOVAH
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:3 states that God appeared to the patriarchs by the name 'God Almighty' but was not known by the name JEHOVAH to them, highlighting a revelation of God's covenant name to Moses.

questions.question: What promise does God make to the children of Israel in Exodus 6:6 that foreshadows the concept of redemption in the New Testament?
options: I will redeem you with a stretched out arm
questions.correctAnswer: I will redeem you with a stretched out arm
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:6 uses the phrase 'redeem you with a stretched out arm,' which foreshadows the New Testament theme of redemption through God's power.

questions.question: Which familial relationship is described in Exodus 6:20 that is significant for the Levitical priesthood?
options: Amram married Jochebed his father's sister
questions.correctAnswer: Amram married Jochebed his father's sister
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:20 highlights that Amram married Jochebed, his father's sister, which establishes the lineage of Moses and Aaron, key figures in the Levitical priesthood.

questions.question: What is the significance of God saying 'I am the LORD' repeatedly in this chapter, especially in Exodus 6:2 and 6:7?
options: It asserts God's identity and covenant faithfulness
It is a poetic refrain with no specific meaning
It refers to a new deity introduced
It is a command to the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: It asserts God's identity and covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: The repeated declaration 'I am the LORD' emphasizes God's sovereign identity and His faithfulness to His covenant promises, as shown in Exodus 6:2 and 6:7.

questions.question: According to Exodus 6:4, what is the nature of the covenant God established with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob?
options: To give them the land of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: To give them the land of Canaan
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:4 explains that God's covenant with the patriarchs included giving their descendants the land of Canaan as an inheritance.

questions.question: In Exodus 6:5, how does God demonstrate His awareness of the Israelites’ suffering?
options: He hears their groaning and remembers His covenant
He tells Moses to ignore their cries
He commands the Egyptians to be merciful
questions.correctAnswer: He hears their groaning and remembers His covenant
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:5 states that God heard the groaning of the Israelites under Egyptian bondage and remembered His covenant, showing divine compassion and purpose.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the sons of Levi listed in Exodus 6:16-19?
questions.correctAnswer: Naphtali
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:16-19 lists Gershon, Kohath, and Merari as the sons of Levi; Naphtali is from a different tribe, not Levi.

questions.question: What is the relationship between Aaron and Elisheba according to Exodus 6:23?
questions.correctAnswer: Elisheba is Aaron's wife
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:23 states that Aaron took Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab, to wife, making her his spouse.

questions.question: How does Exodus 6:12 and 6:30 reveal Moses' self-perception and its impact on his mission?
options: Moses feels he has uncircumcised lips and doubts Pharaoh will listen
Moses is confident and eager to confront Pharaoh
Moses plans to go alone without Aaron
Moses does not believe in God's promise
questions.correctAnswer: Moses feels he has uncircumcised lips and doubts Pharaoh will listen
questions.explanation: Both verses show Moses expressing insecurity about his speech and fearing Pharaoh will not heed him due to his 'uncircumcised lips,' indicating self-doubt in his calling.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Exodus 6:1 where God says 'with a strong hand shall he let them go, and with a strong hand shall he drive them out'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The phrase uses parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to emphasize the certainty and strength of God's deliverance.

questions.question: Exodus 6:8 mentions God bringing the Israelites into a land 'concerning the which I did swear.' What is this an example of in biblical theology?
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant promise
questions.explanation: This phrase refers to the covenant promise God made to the patriarchs about the land of Canaan, a foundational theological theme.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 6:9, the Israelites immediately believed Moses after he spoke to them about God's promises.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:9 states that the Israelites did not listen to Moses because of their anguish and cruel bondage, showing their initial disbelief or despair.

questions.question: In Exodus 6:25, who is identified as the father of Phinehas, a notable priestly figure?
questions.correctAnswer: Eleazar
questions.explanation: Eleazar, Aaron’s son, is noted in Exodus 6:25 as the father of Phinehas, continuing the priestly lineage.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the genealogies in Exodus 6:14-25, especially in relation to the narrative of deliverance?
options: To establish the legitimacy of the Levite leadership
To list all the tribes of Israel
To provide a census for taxation
To recount the history of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To establish the legitimacy of the Levite leadership
questions.explanation: The genealogies emphasize the lineage and authority of Moses, Aaron, and the Levites, legitimizing their role in leading the deliverance.

questions.question: How does Exodus 6:7 reflect the theme of God's personal relationship with Israel that develops throughout the Bible?
options: God will take Israel as His people and be their God
God will remain distant and uninvolved
God will only help them temporarily
God will choose another nation instead
questions.correctAnswer: God will take Israel as His people and be their God
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:7 expresses God's intention to be intimately connected with Israel as their God, a relationship developed throughout Scripture.

theological.title: Exodus Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Exodus Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What name does God reveal to Moses in Exodus 6 that was not known to the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob?
questions.correctAnswer: JEHOVAH
questions.explanation: God declares His name as JEHOVAH to Moses, a name not known to the patriarchs (Exodus 6:3). This reveals God's eternal and self-existent nature, consistent with God's self-revelation in Exodus 3:14 and Psalm 83:18, and affirmed in John 8:58 where Jesus claims 'I AM,' linking to the divine name.

questions.question: According to Exodus 6, what is God's promised method to bring Israel out of Egyptian bondage?
options: With a strong hand and great judgments
questions.correctAnswer: With a strong hand and great judgments
questions.explanation: God promises to redeem Israel with a stretched-out arm and great judgments (Exodus 6:6), demonstrating His omnipotence and justice. This aligns with His mighty acts in salvation history (Psalm 136:12, Isaiah 63:12) and the ultimate deliverance through Christ (Colossians 2:15).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: God said, 'I am the LORD, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I will rid you out of their ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: bondage
questions.explanation: God specifically mentions bringing Israel out of the burdens and bondage of Egypt (Exodus 6:6), emphasizing His role as Redeemer. This theme of deliverance from bondage is echoed in Psalm 107:14, Galatians 5:1, and Romans 8:21, highlighting salvation as liberation.

questions.question: What covenant does God reaffirm in Exodus 6 concerning the land promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob?
options: To give them the land of Canaan as an inheritance
To bless them with many descendants only
To make them a priestly nation
questions.correctAnswer: To give them the land of Canaan as an inheritance
questions.explanation: God reaffirms His covenant to give the land of Canaan to the descendants of the patriarchs as an inheritance (Exodus 6:4, 6:8). This covenant is foundational to biblical theology (Genesis 15:18, Deuteronomy 1:8) and foreshadows the eschatological promise of a new heaven and earth (Revelation 21:1-3).

questions.question: Which statement best describes the response of the Israelites to Moses’ message in Exodus 6?
options: They did not listen because of their anguish and cruel bondage
They asked for signs and wonders
questions.correctAnswer: They did not listen because of their anguish and cruel bondage
questions.explanation: The Israelites did not heed Moses due to their despair and harsh slavery (Exodus 6:9), reflecting human brokenness under suffering. This aligns with the biblical reality of human unbelief in hardship (Psalm 78:17-22, Hebrews 3:7-19), demonstrating the need for divine grace.

questions.question: Who are appointed by God to speak to Pharaoh and bring the Israelites out of Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Aaron
questions.explanation: God commands Moses and Aaron to confront Pharaoh and lead Israel out of Egypt (Exodus 6:13, 6:27). Their roles prefigure Christ and the Spirit's joint mission (John 14:16-17, Hebrews 3:1), emphasizing divine appointment for salvation.

questions.question: What concern does Moses express to the LORD regarding his ability to speak to Pharaoh?
options: He says he has uncircumcised lips
He is concerned about the people’s disbelief
questions.correctAnswer: He says he has uncircumcised lips
questions.explanation: Moses describes his lips as uncircumcised, symbolizing inadequacy or impurity in speech (Exodus 6:12, 6:30). This highlights human weakness before divine mission, paralleling Jeremiah 1:6-9 and Isaiah 6:5-8 where God empowers the reluctant prophet.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a son of Levi in Exodus 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Eleazar
questions.explanation: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari are sons of Levi (Exodus 6:16), while Eleazar is a grandson (son of Aaron, who is son of Amram, son of Kohath) (Exodus 6:23, 6:25). This genealogical detail is important for understanding priestly lineage (Numbers 3:17-39, 1 Chronicles 6:1-3).

questions.question: What relationship does Jochebed have to Amram according to Exodus 6?
questions.correctAnswer: She is his father's sister
questions.explanation: Jochebed is identified as Amram’s father’s sister, emphasizing close kinship marriage (Exodus 6:20). This detail illuminates Israelite family structure and the lineage of Moses and Aaron, relevant for priestly heritage (Numbers 26:59, Exodus 2:1-10).

questions.question: What is the significance of God saying 'I am the LORD' repeatedly in this chapter?
options: It emphasizes His covenant faithfulness and authority
It merely identifies Him as a god among many
It focuses on His wrath only
It is a poetic phrase with no deeper meaning
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes His covenant faithfulness and authority
questions.explanation: The repeated declaration 'I am the LORD' underscores God’s unchanging nature, covenant faithfulness, and supreme authority (Exodus 6:2, 6:6, 6:8, 6:29). This is consistent with themes in Isaiah 40:28, Psalm 110:1, and John 8:58, affirming God's eternal sovereignty.

questions.question: Which descendants are mentioned as the heads of the families of Reuben and Simeon in Exodus 6?
options: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, Carmi; Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, Shaul
Eleazar and Ithamar; Korah and Nepheg
Mishael, Elzaphan, Zithri; Mahali and Mushi
questions.correctAnswer: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, Carmi; Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, Shaul
questions.explanation: Exodus 6:14-15 lists these as heads of Reuben and Simeon's families respectively. These genealogies emphasize tribal identity and continuity (Genesis 46:9-19, Numbers 26), foundational for understanding Israel's corporate structure.

questions.question: What theological truth is conveyed by God saying He will 'take you to me for a people' in Exodus 6?
options: God's covenantal relationship and election of Israel
God will abandon Israel after deliverance
Israel must earn God's favor by works
questions.correctAnswer: God's covenantal relationship and election of Israel
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates God's choosing and adopting Israel as His own people (Exodus 6:7), foundational for covenant theology (Deuteronomy 7:6, Jeremiah 31:33, 1 Peter 2:9) and the church as God's chosen people (1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: How does Exodus 6 portray God's memory of His covenant in relation to Israel's suffering?
options: God has remembered His covenant and heard their groaning
God is indifferent to their bondage
God punishes them for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: God has remembered His covenant and heard their groaning
questions.explanation: God explicitly states He has heard the Israelites' groaning and remembered His covenant (Exodus 6:5), demonstrating His faithfulness and compassion. This is echoed in Psalm 105:8, Isaiah 49:15-16, and Hebrews 8:10, affirming God's commitment to His people despite their trials.

questions.question: Who is the wife of Aaron mentioned in Exodus 6, and who are their children?
questions.correctAnswer: Elisheba; Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, Ithamar
questions.explanation: Elisheba is Aaron’s wife and mother of his four sons as per Exodus 6:23. This genealogical detail is important for the Aaronic priesthood lineage, referenced in Leviticus 10:1-2 and Numbers 3:2-4.

questions.question: What is the significance of God promising to bring Israel into the land He swore to give to their ancestors?
options: It affirms God's faithfulness to His covenant promises
It is a conditional promise based on Israel's merit
It is a temporary promise with no lasting impact
It refers only to earthly blessings
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's faithfulness to His covenant promises
questions.explanation: God’s promise to bring Israel into the promised land (Exodus 6:8) emphasizes His unchanging faithfulness and sovereign plan, consistent with covenantal assurance in Genesis 12:7, Joshua 21:43, and Hebrews 6:13-18. It points to ultimate fulfillment in the new creation (Revelation 21).
